Graphical abstract Oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to 1,3-butadiene over Bi–Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was studied with fixed bed/flow-type reactor at 400–500°C. The γ-Al2O3 support itself showed activity for oxidative dehydrogenation from n-butane to n-butenes as well as partial oxidation to CO. The role of Ni oxide on γ-Al2O3 was confirmed that sole Ni oxide loading until 30wt% Ni on γ-Al2O3 resulted higher activity and selectivity to butadiene by diminishing partial oxidation related to γ-Al2O3 and enhancing conversion to butadiene. The concerted effect of Bi and Ni in Bi–Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was confirmed with two methods: (1) partial or full substitution of Bi for 1/3, 2/3 and 3/3 Ni of 30wt% Ni on γ-Al2O3, and (2) various amounts of Bi addition to 20wt% Ni on γ-Al2O3. As for (1) Bi substitution, 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni showed higher activity and selectivity than the others. As for (2) Bi addition, it until Bi/Ni=0.82 (60wt% Bi-20wt% Ni) lead to suppressed CO/H2 production and improved conversion to butadiene. 30wt% Bi-20wt% Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showing the highest butadiene selectivity of about 47% at 450°C was used to confirm the relation between the state of oxygen and the reaction pathways by changing reaction condition factors, oxygen-to-butane ratio and temperature. It was revealed by catalyst characterization that the catalyst of Bi modified and Ni oxide highly loaded on γ-Al2O3 has high activity and selectivity for oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene due to either an improved Ni dispersion and redox property or a couple of weak acidity and moderate basicity. Keywords Oxidative dehydrogenation n-butane Butadiene Binary oxide Impregnation 1 Introduction Butadiene is an important petrochemical feedstock to manufacture petrochemicals and materials for industries including automotive, paints, textile, appliance manufacturing and others. Its main application segments include styrene-butadiene rubber (SBR), polybutadiene rubber (PBR), acrylonitrile butadiene styrene resins (ABS), styrene butadiene latex (SB Latex), adiponitrile, and nitrile rubber (NR). Currently there is a renewed interest for butadiene supply especially from Asia-Pacific markets largely driven by automotive sector [1]. The butadiene is mainly obtained as a byproduct from naphtha cracker to manufacture ethylene and propylene. The butadiene is also produced by n-butane based catalytic direct dehydrogenation process over chromium/alumina catalysts at temperature approximately 600–680°C [2]. At such high operating condition, thermal cracking of hydrocarbon occurs and frequent catalyst regeneration is required due to coke deposition. Several Pt or Cr based alumina catalysts were extensively studied for direct dehydrogenation process of n-butane to light olefins, not focused on butadiene [3–9]. As our previous work, supported Cr–V catalysts were investigated for direct dehydrogenation process of n-butane to butadiene [10]. However, as this direct dehydrogenation process to produce butadiene is required by high temperature operation due to thermodynamic equilibrium to butadiene, it inevitably causes the formation of excessive coke and quick deactivation of catalyst system. Furthermore, co-existence of carbon dioxide in the direct dehydrogenation process over the supported Cr–V catalyst was studied to lower the operation temperature with hydrogen removal by reverse water-gas shift reaction. The effect was still rather limited, as shown in our previous paper [11]. On the other hand, oxidative dehydrogenation with oxygen can be carried out at relatively lower reaction temperature. The process is not limited by thermodynamic equilibrium and the catalyst deactivation is reduced due to the presence of oxygen [12,13]. However, in oxidative dehydrogenation, selective oxidation of n-butane to 1,3-butadiene is challenging. High temperature are required to activate n-butane, while dehydrogenated products (i.e., butenes and butadiene) react rapidly with oxygen to form stable combustion products like carbon dioxide and water [12,14]. A suitable catalyst is needed to overcome this limitation by operating at relatively less reaction temperature at lower O2/n-C4 ratio. It has been generally recognized that the catalytic activity and selectivity for oxidative dehydrogenation are related to the redox property and surface acid–base character. For the redox property, the catalyst lattice oxygen participates in oxidation reaction for hydrogen and hydrocarbon intermediates. And then the reduced catalyst surface is restored to its earlier oxidation state by adsorption of oxygen from gas phase. The evolution of lattice oxygen is usually promoted by the interaction between metal oxides of the components [15]. A number of catalysts have been investigated for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to preferably butenes, including V–MgO [16–18], Ni–Mo–O [19,20], MoO3/MgO [21], titanium pyrophosphate [12] and V2O5/SiO2 [13]. In such catalytic systems, despite high dehydrogenation activity, selectivity with respect to butadiene is very low. For instance, it was reported over titanium pyrophosphate catalyst that the maximum n-butane conversion was of 28% and selectivity to dehydrogenation products was of 47%, while the formation of butadiene remained at about 14% and less compared to butenes (33%) [12]. It was reported over vanadia dispersed SiO2 catalyst that the predominant reaction products were butenes (1-butene, trans and cis-2-butene), while 1,3-butadiene product selectivity was minor (16%) along with cracking products [13]. In the previous literatures, most of the works are related to the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane mainly to butenes. In such cases, the selectivity to butenes occurs by inner CH group activation of butane on the acid centers of catalyst surface. For selective butadiene formation, further activation of second CH group of butenes is needed. In such case, the literature dealing with desired characteristics of catalyst (both acid and base) are limited and needed to be investigated. Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 based catalysts have attracted much attention for oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene, where nickel sites seem to be the active centers for ethane activation [22,23]. The catalyst concept for the ethane oxidative dehydrogenation over Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 based catalysts was considered as also effective against an activation of methyl CH bond at the end of n-butane and n-butenes. On the other hand, as for supported NiO catalyst in our previous work [24], nano-sized porous γ-Al2O3 was found as an effective support for preparing NiO based multicomponent catalyst equivalent to co-precipitated or powder mixed one. This technology of the supported NiO based multicomponent catalyst was applied and extended to study the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene. First, activity and selectivity over the γ-Al2O3 support itself were confirmed. Second, the effect of NiO loading on the dehydrogenation performance were studied over a series of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different nickel contents increased until saturated value (ca. 30wt%). Third, the combination of Bi and Ni oxide on γ-Al2O3 for the activity and selectivity were confirmed with two methods: (1) partial or full substitution of Bi oxide for Ni oxide of 30wt% Ni on γ-Al2O3 catalyst and (2) various amounts of Bi addition to 20wt% Ni on γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Fourth, the catalyst with the best performance was investigated on the reaction pathways by changing reaction condition factors, oxygen-to-butane ratio and temperature. Finally, the catalytic performances due to NiO loading, Bi oxide substitution for NiO and Bi addition were discussed with characterizations of structure, redox property, acidity and basicity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The nano-sized porous γ-Al2O3 (pore diameter: 11nm, and pore volume: 0.75cc/g) calcined at 550°C was synthesized by successfully pH-controlled precipitation method using aluminum nitrate and sodium aluminate as precursors of boehmite and an acid–base pair of precipitating reagents according to detailed preparation technique as described by Kimura et al. [25]. 5–30wt% nickel impregnated γ-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness technique. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99%, Fisher Scientific) commercially available was used as nickel source without further purification. The binary oxide Bi–Ni–O/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by co-impregnation technique. For 20wt% Bi-10wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, 0.49g of nickel nitrate hexahydrate Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 80ml of deionized water. After dissolution, 0.46g of bismuth nitrate pentahydrate Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (98%, Fluka-Garantie) was added to the above solution and the resultant suspension was stirred for dissolution. Then 1g of γ-Al2O3 was added and left overnight for impregnation. After impregnation, the sample was dried at 120°C for 3h to obtain an as-prepared catalyst. The binary oxide catalysts with different bismuth content (4wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 30wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 60wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, and 30wt% Bi/γ-Al2O3) were also prepared in similar manner. For consistency between catalyst characterization and catalytic evaluation the as-prepared catalysts were served to the both experiments after activation and stabilization by calcination at 370°C for 3h followed by 590°C for 2h under flowing air. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The BET surface area and pore structure of catalysts were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument (Norcross, GA). Before adsorption measurements, samples (ca. 0.1g) were degassed at 240°C for 3h under nitrogen flow. The nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196°C). Powder XRD analyses of the catalysts were carried out using Rigaku Miniflex II desktop X-ray diffractometer in a diffraction angle (2θ) range of 5–80° with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5406Å) at operating parameters of 30mA and 40kV with a step size of 0.02° and speed of 2°/min. TPR and TPD (temperature-programmed reduction and desorption) experiments were performed in BEL-CAT-A-200 chemisorption apparatus. The equipment consists of quartz sample holder with high temperature furnace, and a pair of a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a mass spectrometer. The linearity of the TCD response was established by the injection of gas pulses of known volume in helium background flow. H2-TPR analysis was performed using Ar/H2 gas mixture (95/5vol%). The total flow rate of the gas mixture was 50cm3/min. The sample (100mg) was preheated in He at 300°C for 3h, and then cooled to room temperature. Then the sample was heated at 20°C/min to the final temperature of 900°C. The H2 consumption was measured by a thermal conductivity detector and CuO was used as a reference for the calibration of H2 consumption. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was carried out on the same instrument with substantially the same procedure to measure acidity. The procedure of NH3-TPD is as follows. The catalyst sample (100mg) was pretreated regularly in a flow of He (50mL/min) at 500°C for 1h. Then the sample was exposed to He/NH3 mixture (95/5vol%) at 100°C for 30min. The gas phase NH3 was removed by He purging for 1h followed by which TPD was performed in He flow (50mL/min) at a heating rate of 10°C/min, and the desorbed NH3 was monitored by either a TCD detector or a mass spectroscopy. Temperature programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) was carried out on the same instrument with substantially the same procedure to measure basicity. In the case of CO2-TPD, the gas phase is He/CO2 mixture (95/5vol%). 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic runs were carried out in a fully integrated, fixed bed continuous flow-type reactor system (BELCAT). The system consists of one tubular quartz reactor attached with stainless steel one-zone furnace assembly through reactor furnace wall thermo well. The as-prepared catalyst sample (0.30g) was packed in the reactor and pretreated to activate and stabilize as a catalyst under flowing air at higher temperature. The reaction test started after cooling-down to the reaction test temperature under flowing nitrogen. The flow rate of reactant (n-butane and air) and N2 were controlled at appropriate proportions. In the study on the oxidative dehydrogenation, the oxygen to hydrocarbon ratio (O2/n-C4H10) and temperature is considered to play a decisive role in the catalytic selectivity. The catalyst evaluation was operated selecting the reaction conditions at different temperatures (400–500°C) and under different feed ratio of oxygen to n-butane (O2/n-C4H10 =1–4mol/mol). The effluent was analyzed online by using a GC system (Agilent, 7890N). One GC equipped with FID and GC-GasPro capillary column (L: 60m and ID: 0.32mm) was used to analyze hydrocarbons and oxygenates. The other GC with TCD and ShinCarbon 80/100 mesh SS column (He carrier) and MS5A 60/80 mesh SS column (Ar carrier) were used to detect the gases, N2, O2, CO and CO2, and H2, respectively. The products were identified by comparison with standard samples. Conversion of n-butane and selectivity to products was calculated based on the balance of carbon. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic evaluation 3.1.1 Effect of nickel loading over γ-Al2O3 The effects of the nickel loadings over γ-Al2O3 varied as 0, 5, 10, 20 and 30wt% on the activity as the conversion and the selectivity at 400, 450 and 500°C are shown in Fig. 1 and Fig. 2 , respectively. The main products in the effluent were obtained from dehydrogenation (DH: 1-butene, t-2-butene, cis-2-butene, 1,3-butadiene), cracking (CR: mainly ethylene and propylene), and partial oxidation (PO: CO), while CO2, CH4, C2H6, C3H8 and oxygen containing products were also detected as the negligible carbon-containing products from GC analysis. First, Figs. 1 and 2 revealed that the support γ-Al2O3 itself (Ni=0wt%) shows nearly half activity and lower selectivity of 5wt% Ni loaded catalyst. At 400°C, the butane conversion was 5.2%, and the product selectivity of dehydrogenation to butenes (C4 =), partial oxidation and cracking was 44.3%, 47.3% and 8.4%, respectively. With an increase of the reaction temperature, the conversion increased until 27%, while the selectivity of the dehydrogenation decreased to 22%, the selectivity of partial oxidation and cracking increased to 60% and 18%, respectively. At any temperature, butadiene production was nearly not detected. Second, the conversion and selectivity changed with nickel loading, as shown in Figs. 1 and 2. As for the catalytic activity of nickel loaded catalysts, the conversions at 400°C over 5wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 10wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, and 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 increased to 10%, 11%, 12% and 15%, respectively. At 450°C, the butane conversion rose to the maximum of 26% over 5wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and then decreased to stabilize at about 21% over other three catalysts. At 500°C, the 5wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed high conversion of butane of about 39%, which then gradually reduced to about 33%, 26% and 25% over 10wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, and 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, respectively. On the other hand as the product distribution shown in Fig. 2, dehydrogenation selectivity not only to butenes but also to butadiene improved in turn to the aim with an increase of Ni loading at each temperature. With increasing nickel loading (Ni=5, 10, 20 and 30wt%) at 400°C, the dehydrogenation selectivity to the total of butenes and butadiene reached the maximum of 90% with nickel loading of 30wt%. Particularly, the butadiene selectivity (C4 2=) started at almost 0% and reached 30%. Reversely, the partial oxidation selectivity (PO) dominant over γ-Al2O3 support was favorably decreased to less than 10%, resulting in the highest butadiene selectivity. The cracking selectivity (CR) shown over γ-Al2O3 remained nearly constant after Ni loading. At higher temperatures, the behavior of the selectivity was similar to the obtained at 400°C, except that the selectivity of the partial oxidation and cracking was higher at each Ni loading and remained at higher levels even after 30wt% Ni loading than these at 400°C. Therefore, this study shows that conversion to butadiene and its selectivity are due in good part to the nickel species and its character, which were controlled by supporting on the specific γ-Al2O3. 3.1.2 Bi–Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst 3.1.2.1 Influence of bismuth substitution over 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst Based on the performance as shown in Figs. 1 and 2, 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 was chosen as the start catalyst to study the concerted effect of Bi–Ni by bismuth substitution. The overall metal loading over γ-Al2O3 was maintained at 30wt%, while bismuth to total metal loading weight ratio was subsequently varied among 1/3, 2/3 and 1. The activity was compared with 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3. Fig. 3 shows the butane conversion and the product distribution. The conversion over 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 was the highest of 23%, while decreased to the lowest of 13% over 30wt% Bi/γ-Al2O3 in volcano shape. The product distribution profile showed the clear influence of bismuth substitution. Considering the product selectivity, 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 also showed the highest selectivity of dehydrogenation and butadiene production than 30wt% Ni, 20wt% Bi-10wt% Ni and 30wt% Bi in volcano shape. The further enhanced butadiene selectivity can be clearly related to the partial substitution of bismuth for nickel. The partial oxidation changed significantly until less than 3% as the bottom at 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni in valley shape, while the cracking increased until near 30% as the top at 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni in volcano shape. In the study on the partial substitution of bismuth for nickel in the catalyst, 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest selectivity for either dehydrogenation or butadiene and low selectivity for partial oxidation and cracking so that the 20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 was selected as the start catalyst for bismuth addition study. 3.1.2.2 Effect of bismuth addition to 20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 In order to obtain any further improvement, the bismuth content was gradually increased as 4, 10, 30 and 60wt% at fixed nickel loading of 20wt%. The 4, 10, 30 and 60wt% bismuth addition corresponds to 0.05, 0.14, 0.41 and 0.82 of Bi/Ni molar ratio, respectively. As shown in Fig. 4 , the conversion of butane kept nearly constant in low hill shape at 22%, 25%, 24%, 23% and 22% over Ni/γ-Al2O3, Bi0.05Ni/γ-Al2O3, Bi0.14Ni/γ-Al2O3, Bi0.41Ni/γ-Al2O3, and Bi0.82Ni/γ-Al2O3, respectively. In the product distribution, the selectivity to dehydrogenation and butadiene improved with Bi/Ni ratio from 73% to 92%, respectively. The Bi0.41Ni/γ-Al2O3 (30wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3) catalyst showed the highest butane selectivity with negligible selectivity of partial oxidation, while the cracking selectivity was not clearly influenced by the bismuth addition within the studied extent. 3.1.3 Influence of reaction condition over Bi–Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst 3.1.3.1 O2/n-C4H10 ratio Using this catalyst, 30wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 as the standard Bi–Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the reaction pathways related to catalyst sites was investigated by changing reaction condition factors, oxygen-to-butane ratio and temperature. The oxygen to hydrocarbon ratio (O2/n-C4H10) is considered to play a decisive role in catalytic activity and selectivity. As shown in Fig. 5 , the conversion of butane mainly producing butenes (C4 =) and butadiene (BD) increased not proportionally but linearly with increase of O2/n-C4H10 molar ratio from 1 to 4. However, the cracking selectivity increased in 2nd order curve. The product selectivity of butenes decreased instead, while the butadiene selectivity kept nearly constant. The very low selectivity of partial oxidation (PO) increased similarly to that of cracking (see Table 1 ). The result from partial oxidation selectivity is in line with previous reports [26–28], demonstrating that oxidation reactions leading to partial oxidation formation have a strong dependence on oxygen amount. Considering either (i) the tradeoff relation of the product selectivity between butanes and the cracked or (ii) the analogy of the selectivity dependence on the oxygen to hydrocarbon ratio between the cracking and the partial oxidation, the cracked products were thought as decarbonated derivatives of carboxylic acids from n-butenes through oxidation by oxygen. 3.1.3.2 Reaction temperature In order to investigate further on reaction pathway over the Bi–Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the effect of temperature on the activity and selectivity was studied at the extent of 400 to 500°C, as shown in Fig. 6 . With increase of reaction temperature until 450°C, the conversion of butane increased and it did not changed more than 450°C. However, the butadiene increased continuously until 500°C, while the selectivity of the cracking and butenes was very similar to that with the oxygen to hydrocarbon ratio. The formation of partial oxidation remained at low level with a slight increase (see Table 1). These results suggest that the cracking reaction and the partial oxidation occur separately on activated oxygen sites and other concentrated oxygen sites, respectively. Bi effect on the reaction selectivity works probably only toward reducing the concentrated oxygen sites for the partial oxidation by increasing oxygen mobility to consume at the sites for butene dehydrogenation to butadiene. Therefore, in order to suppress the cracking reaction, the other modifier to the support may be selected among reagent reducing oxygen species for oxygenate formation, because the cracking activity exists over the γ-Al2O3 itself. 3.1.4 Effectiveness of oxidative hydrogen removal In some cases of the reaction test, small amounts of H2 were observed in the product effluent. H2 formation through simple dehydrogenation of n-butane is reversible and the dehydrogenation conversion is thermodynamically limited to a low level. Therefore, in order to explain the advantage of the catalyst system in this work for n-butane oxidative dehydrogenation, the hydrogen amounts hypothesized from reactions of dehydrogenation and partial oxidation were compared to the effluent H2. Furthermore, in order to clarify the effect of the factors due to either the catalysts (Ni loading and the bismuth substitution/addition) or reaction condition (O2/n-C4H10 ratio and temperature) on the selectivity, effectiveness of oxidative hydrogen removal was discussed from the observed hydrogen amount in the reaction effluent and the hydrogen balance based on the reaction selectivity. The effluent hydrogen molecule was compared with the hypothetical calculated amount from the reactions, as shown in Table 1. Ni/γ-Al2O3 is well-known as either a dry/steam reforming catalyst or a water-gas shift catalyst. CO and H2 from dry/steam reforming with water-gas shift reaction are probably contributed to H2 formation. But CO2 and the steam are not in the feedstock but the product from the first step reaction contributing to the second step reaction. And the increase of Ni loading makes the selectivity of partial oxidation (CO formation) decrease. Furthermore, even when CO and H2 from dry/steam reforming are included as the second step reaction, the ratio of CO to H2 as a total equation is not so changed from direct partial oxidation of n-butane. According to this consideration, stoichiometry of direct partial oxidation was representatively adapted to the calculation of H2 formation from the produced CO. The hydrogen produced by partial oxidation looks like released into the product effluent as molecular hydrogen except γ-Al2O3 itself and only Bi loaded γ-Al2O3, on which the partial oxidation may occur through another route without formation of molecular hydrogen. For example, CO may be produced from strongly adsorbed butadiene or more dehydrogenated, because in the case of both catalysts the butadiene production was very low. The released hydrogen probably holds some influence on the butadiene production through thermodynamic equilibrium. As the result, it has been confirmed that the hydrogen atoms withdrawn from n-butane and butenes are effectively removed through oxidative dehydrogenation without H2 formation. And the observed hydrogen molecule was assumed as the product from partial oxidation, independently from dehydrogenation of n-butane and butenes. To make it more clear, Fig. 7 : effect of Bi amount to Ni on H2 formation at 450°C, O2/C4 =2 [mol/mol] has been included as the typical example figure of the comparison. The O2 conversions as measured from O2 concentration difference between the reactor inlet and outlet are shown in Table 1. The O2 conversions suggest the existence of unassigned consumer except for oxidative dehydrogenation and partial oxidation. According to the result of this consideration, the cracked products, mainly ethylene and propylene, were considered to be secondary products from oxygenates, i.e., maleic acid and butenic acid, through decarbonation (deCO2). Oxygenates as liquid product, i.e., maleic acid and butenic acid, are also candidates as oxygen consumers. Though they were measured only as the trace, the oxygen conversion suggests that the oxygenate production probably occurs at the extent similar to the cracked production. Therefore, in future, the catalyst should be redesigned to improve the selectivity of O2 conversion by suppressing oxygenate formation. In the summary of the catalytic evaluation, the suppression of the partial oxidation by Bi modification to Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst directly leads to an improvement for the butadiene production. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Surface area and porosity The surface areas of γ-Al2O3, Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Bi–NiO/γ-Al2O3 samples are presented in Table 2 . γ-Al2O3 showed the BET surface area of 276m2/g. 5wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 10wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 exhibited higher surface than γ-Al2O3 support itself, which then decreased significantly over 30wt% nickel impregnation to 180m2/g. The substitution of 10wt% and 20wt% bismuth oxide for 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed lower surface area than 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 at about 172m2/g and 134m2/g, respectively. 30wt% Bi/γ-Al2O3 showed the surface area of 144m2/g, which is still enough to work as the catalyst. The substantial surface area, which is calculated by volume based alumina showed the presence of high surface area over 5–20wt% nickel impregnation, which then decreased with 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 to 248m2/g (Table 2). The fact suggests that Ni oxide dispersed as fine particles holds additional high surface area. The surface area and pore volume calculated from BJH adsorption exhibited similar characteristics pattern, where the addition of 30wt% Ni showed a decrease in the surface area indicating filling of fractal surface area of alumina. On the other hand, the high porosity of γ-Al2O3 support was kept after a large amount of Bi and Ni loading, as shown in Table 2 and Fig. 8 . Therefore, the results in the catalyst evaluation are considered to reflect the chemical character of the surface. 3.2.2 X-ray diffraction The XRD diffraction patterns for nickel and bismuth–nickel impregnated samples are shown in Fig. 9 . The diffraction patterns of γ-Al2O3 with primary 2θ peaks at 46° and 67° (JCPDS 10-425) distinguished in all the samples is available as the internal standard. The characteristic reflections of NiO are present at 2θ values equal to 9°, 20° and 60°. The samples with 5–30wt% Ni loaded showed diffraction peaks corresponding to the presence of NiO species. It is well-known rather difficult to identify the diffraction patterns of NiO compound supported on γ-Al2O3 because of the overlap between γ-Al2O3 and Ni Al2O4 peaks, when the crystallite size of the dispersed NiO species on support is near detection limit of XRD. However, the diffraction peaks corresponding to nickel oxide were observed proportionally along nickel amount with increased nickel loading, as shown in Fig. 9. In addition, the nickel species showed nano-meter sized crystalline phase as evidenced by the broad peaks equivalent to the peaks of γ-Al2O3. The fact by the broad peaks is in good agreement with the high surface area of these samples that reflects finer particles dispersed on the alumina (Table 2). While the formation of NiAl2O4 phase with nickel addition is well-known to cause the diffraction peak of alumina shift toward lower angle indicating diffusion of NiO particles into the support, no appreciable shift is observed in the present study because of calcination at the controlled temperature not to NiAl2O4 phase. The XRD profiles of Bi substituted catalyst 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 showed positive effect on Ni dispersion in comparison with 20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3. The diffraction patterns of α-Bi2O3 and β-Bi2O3 with sharp primary 2θ peaks (JCPDS 41-1449) increased with bismuth substitution in the samples 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 20wt% Bi-10wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 30wt% Bi/γ-Al2O3. The crystalline size of the Bi2O3 observed by XRD is too large to modify NiO species because of the low surface area. The large crystalline probably fills up fractal pore surface to make smooth in good agreement with the decreasing of surface area on these samples (Table 2). This fact suggests that Bi effect on NiO works through face-to-face contacting between NiO and the other part of Bi species by forming very fine particles in some binary oxide phase undetected by XRD. This suggestion was also supported by TPR and NH3/CO2 TPD as the effect causes changes of chemical characters. 3.2.3 Temperature programmed reduction In general for oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes, the reaction is considered to proceed via redox mechanism, in which the reducibility of active sites is a key factor for the catalyst activity [29]. In order to measure the reducibility of NiO species and metal oxide support interaction, TPR analyses were performed. Fig. 10 shows the TPR profiles of γ-Al2O3, 5–30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 20wt% Bi-10wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 30wt% Bi/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The reduction peak maxima as well as the amount of H2 uptake (mmol/g) was summarized in Table 3 . For γ-Al2O3, a small peak is observed corresponding to adsorbed O2 being removed from surface of support. The results showed that nickel impregnated samples exhibited two reduction peaks (200–750°C). With increasing nickel loading, the increase of the both peaks was observed. The first reduction peak located at about 317°C moderately shifted to 278°C with growing along Ni loading. A new shoulder peak at about 350–500°C on low temperature slope of the second peak was gradually observed. As for Bi substitution for Ni/γ-Al2O3, the shoulder was more clearly identified as a peak in the case of 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, the first peak of which shifted toward the lowest temperature 274°C. The shoulder peak lying between 380–545°C indicates the generation of easily reducible nickel oxide species by Bi species from difficultly reducible one on the γ-Al2O3. However, increasing the bismuth substitution (20wt% Bi), and decreasing the nickel content (10wt%) over γ-Al2O3 dramatically reverted the first peak from 274°C to 338°C as an excess rebound. A distinct peaks ascribed to the reduction of Bi2O3 is as the first at 380 and as the main 584°C for 30wt% Bi/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The first peak with sharp reduction at low temperature is attributed to the reduced NiO species at the reaction temperature existing on the edge-side of NiO crystalline, which increases the percentage in total Ni and the freedom from the γ-Al2O3 surface by the stacking along Ni loading in accordance with crystalline size data from XRD. It is considered that the reduced NiO species work as active sites for either the first step dehydrogenation or molecular hydrogen formation in the partial oxidation reaction. The similar consideration leads the shoulder peak at about 350–500°C is attributed to the NiO species on the crystal step side. It is implied that the species work as active sites for the second step dehydrogenation to butadiene and suppress the partial oxidation due to reduced oxygen concentration on its surface linking with the reduced NiO species as the redox system. The redox system is accelerated under the controlled oxygen diffusion by Bi species so that the partial oxidation on the concentrated oxygen sites is also suppressed. The activated oxygen sites for oxidative hydroxylation to the cracking reaction are probably related to the first edge attached to γ-Al2O3 surface because the reaction is less influenced with the increase of Ni loading and accelerated by Bi species in Bi–Ni oxide catalyst system independently from the partial oxidation. 3.2.4 Temperature programmed desorption (NH3/CO2) Fig. 11 shows the acidity of 0–30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Bi–NiO/γ-Al2O3 samples studied by temperature programmed desorption technique (TPD). The acid amount deconvolved to the strength groups were calculated from the deconvolved amounts of the desorbed NH3. The results are presented in Table 4. The NH3-TPD spectra showed an initial desorption peak around 180°C accompanied with a broad desorption shoulder extending upto 500°C. In the case of 5wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, the acid amount was markedly larger (0.257mmol/g), which then decreased to as low as 0.179mmol/g with 30wt% Ni loading. In the case of bismuth modified catalyst 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, the acid amount (0.171mmol/g) was similar to that of 30wt% Ni loading and the presence of less intense desorption peak at high temperature suggest the elimination of strong acid sites. This indicates the addition of 10wt% Bi over 20wt% Ni does not affect the acidity. It was observed that, when bismuth addition increased to 20wt% and nickel loading decreased to 10wt%, the acid amount corresponding to the strong acid sites of the catalyst increased significantly (0.310mmol/g). This clearly shows that addition of 20wt% bismuth decreased the dispersion of nickel atom over alumina support. In the case of 30wt% Bi/γ-Al2O3, the presence of weak, medium and strong acid sites are clearly observed (Table 4 .). The basicity of samples was measured using CO2-TPD (Fig. 12 ). The sample 5wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 showed the highest capacity to adsorb CO2 with two distinct desorption peaks centered at about 188°C and 270°C. The low temperature desorption peak was assigned to the low-strength basic sites, which resulted from the interaction between CO2 with weak basic surface hydroxyl groups. The increased loading of nickel amount found to decrease the CO2 adsorption capacity. However, the strength of the basic character increased, leading to the shift of desorption temperature greater than 300°C. Significantly, the loading of 10wt% bismuth to 20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 found to reverse the basic characteristics similar to those found with 5wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3. The increased loading of bismuth to 20wt%, and decreasing the nickel content to 10wt% tended to lower that basicity but the strength increased with an extra shift in the desorption peaks greater than 350°C. The latter peak is probably due to high-strength basic sites. The impregnation of bismuth oxide of 30wt% over alumina showed no significant basic character compared to all other catalysts Table 4 As the characterization of the spent (after testing) catalyst might also provide valuable information to determine the state of nickel species, i.e., metallic or oxidized. The state of Ni species of the catalyst was confirmed by XRD and color of the spent sample to be stably oxidized (nano-sized NiO and light green: Ni2+, respectively) even after 10h-on-stream of the reaction test. With respect to the activity and the selectivity, they are also stable without any results suggesting change of the catalyst characteristics as far as the catalysts were tested. In general, the presence of gray color indicates the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0. Therefore, the characterization of the fresh (just after calcination at 590°C for stabilization) catalyst itself is considered sufficient to give valuable information about catalytic character Table 4. The activities and selectivities in the oxidation reactions are possibly governed either by redox character or by the acid–base properties of the catalyst and the reactant [30]. The dehydrogenated products, butenes and butadiene, are considered to be basic compounds because of their double bonds. The basicity of butadiene is greater than that of butenes. A necessary condition for an effective catalyst for the production of dehydrogenated basic compounds is the possession of sufficient basic property for desorption. Similar trends were observed with our results (Figs. 1 and 2). γ-Al2O3 and 5–10wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are acidic (Fig. 11) and as the result, the overall selectivity to butadiene was lower than that over 20–30wt% nickel loading. Interestingly, in the case of 10wt% Bi20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, the acidity remains similar to that of 30wt% Ni loading, but generation of strong basic sites is seen with bismuth addition (Fig. 12), which leads to enhanced butadiene formation (Fig. 3–5). The bismuth addition proposed to rationalize the over oxidative ability of nickel atoms from butadiene to CO formation (Fig. 10). However substituting nickel content with 20wt% bismuth is found to increase the basicity of the catalyst, which subsequently increases cracking and partial oxidation product formation (Figs. 3–5 and Table 1). This shows that apart from butadiene formation, the formation of ethylene, propylene shows that other route (involving carboxylic acid) is created. This kind of cracking is related to bismuth oxide, where lattice oxygen of bismuth oxide influences the formation of these products. The catalyst characterization on the bismuth added nickel alumina also supports the observed catalytic evaluation results. 3.3 Modeling of catalyst and reaction Fig. 13 (i) and (ii) shows the simplified scheme of Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Bi–NiO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene. The catalytic evaluation showed that over 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, the butane conversion and butadiene selectivity are high. The influence of bismuth substitution with nickel (10wt% Bi20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, 20wt% Bi10wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3) over γ-Al2O3 was investigated for improved butadiene formation (Fig. 3). The activity was compared with 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 30wt% Bi/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The study showed that the dehydrogenation activity is effectively increased with bismuth substitution. The conversion reaches the maximum with 10wt% bismuth and 20wt% Ni loading and then the activity drops with further increased bismuth substitution (Fig. 3). In the case of sole nickel impregnated sample 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3, partial oxidation product dominates, while with 30Bi/γ-Al2O3, the cracking products dominate and increased to the maximum of 29.6%. Remarkably, 10wt% Bi20wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 showed high butadiene selectivity (Fig. 3). The formation of partial oxidation and cracking product remains less than over 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 30Bi/γ-Al2O3. 4 Conclusions The oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene was studied over 0–30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Bi–NiO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at different O2/n-C4 ratio (1–4mol/mol) in the temperature range of 400–500°C. The influence of bismuth was studied by varying Bi/Ni loading ratio (0.5 and 2) over γ-Al2O3. The activity was compared with 30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 30wt% Bi/γ-Al2O3. The catalysts were characterized by BET/porosity, XRD, H2-TPR and NH3/CO2-TPD measurement techniques. The Bi-Ni oxide interaction affected the reduction behavior of the catalysts, and facilities the reduction of the nickel oxide surface species. Highly loaded Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed better 1,3-butadiene selectivity. TPR analysis of 5–30wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 samples showed two reduction steps substantially associated with NiO species. Nickel loading of 5–30wt% found to increase the reducibility due to NiO crystalline stacking. With bismuth addition, further shifts in the reduction temperature toward lower temperature were observed. The catalyst characterizations supported the catalyst evaluation results. It was revealed that the catalyst of Bi modified and Ni oxide highly loaded on γ-Al2O3 have high activity and selectivity for oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene due to either an improved Ni dispersion and redox property or a couple of weak acidity and moderate basicity. coredata.dc:description: Oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to 1,3-butadiene over Bi–Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was studied with fixed bed/flow-type reactor at 400–500°C. The γ-Al2O3 support itself showed activity for oxidative dehydrogenation from n-butane to n-butenes as well as partial oxidation to CO. The role of Ni oxide on γ-Al2O3 was confirmed that sole Ni oxide loading until 30wt% Ni on γ-Al2O3 resulted higher activity and selectivity to butadiene by diminishing partial oxidation related to γ-Al2O3 and enhancing conversion to butadiene. The concerted effect of Bi and Ni in Bi–Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was confirmed with two methods: (1) partial or full substitution of Bi for 1/3, 2/3 and 3/3 Ni of 30wt% Ni on γ-Al2O3, and (2) various amounts of Bi addition to 20wt% Ni on γ-Al2O3. As for (1) Bi substitution, 10wt% Bi-20wt% Ni showed higher activity and selectivity than the others. As for (2) Bi addition, it until Bi/Ni=0.82 (60wt% Bi-20wt% Ni) lead to suppressed CO/H2 production and improved conversion to butadiene. 30wt% Bi-20wt% Ni oxide/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showing the highest butadiene selectivity of about 47% at 450°C was used to confirm the relation between the state of oxygen and the reaction pathways by changing reaction condition factors, oxygen-to-butane ratio and temperature. It was revealed by catalyst characterization that the catalyst of Bi modified and Ni oxide highly loaded on γ-Al2O3 has high activity and selectivity for oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene due to either an improved Ni dispersion and redox property or a couple of weak acidity and moderate basicity.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene over Bi–Ni–O/γ-alumina catalyst
